questions.question: A unit of measurement of pressure is:
Which of the following are the correct SI units?
options: (a) Density is kilograms per cubic metre,  force is newtons.
(b) Density is newtons per cubic metre, force is kilograms.
(c) Density is kilograms per newton, force is newton-metre squared.
(d) Density is kilograms per square metre, force is kilograms.
questions.solution: (a) Density is kilograms per cubic metre,  force is newtons.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of density?

At a constant CAS when flying below sea level an aircraft will have:
options: (a) a higher TAS than at sea level.
(b) a lower TAS than at sea level at ISA conditions.
(c) the same TAS as at sea level.
(d) the same TAS, but an increased IAS.
questions.solution: (a) a higher TAS than at sea level.

questions.question: Static pressure acts:
TAS          is:

(b) lower than the speed of the undisturbed airstream around the aircraft.

(d) equal to IAS, multiplied by air density at sea level.
questions.solution: (a) higher than the speed of the undisturbed airstream around the aircraft.

questions.solution: (a) dynamic pressure increases and static pressure increases.

questions.solution: (a) the mass flow remains constant and velocity V decreases.

questions.question: Lift and drag respectively are normal and parallel to:

questions.solution: (a) the angle between the relative airflow and the horizontal axis.

questions.question: What is the angle of attack?
options: (a) Angle of the chord line to the relative free stream flow.
(b) Angle of the chord line to the fuselage datum.
(c) Angle of the tailplane chord to the wing chord.
(d) Angle of the tailplane chord to the fuselage datum.
questions.solution: (a) Angle of the chord line to the relative free stream flow.

questions.solution: (a) they are only normal to each other at one angle of attack.

questions.question: When an aircraft enters ground effect:
options: (a) the lift vector is inclined rearwards which increases the thrust required.
(b) the lift vector is inclined forwards which reduces the thrust required.
(c) the lift vector is unaffected, the cushion of air increases.
(d) the lift vector is inclined forward which increases the thrust required.
questions.solution: (a) the lift vector is inclined rearwards which increases the thrust required.

questions.question: When an aircraft enters ground effect:
options: (a) the induced angle of attack increases.
(d) the aircraft will be partially supported on a cushion of air.
questions.solution: (a) the induced angle of attack increases.

options: (d) to the left of the origin.

questions.solution: (a) Air spilling from the top surface to the bottom surface at the wing tip.

(b) top to bottom round the trailing edge.
(c) bottom to top round wing tip.

questions.solution: (a) L/D is maximum at the speed for minimum total drag.

questions.question: What is the cause of induced angle of attack?
options: (a) Downwash from trailing edge in the vicinity of the wing tips.

questions.question: When compared to a laminar boundary layer:
options: (a) a turbulent boundary layer has more kinetic energy.
(b) a turbulent boundary layer is thinner.
(c) less skin friction is generated by a turbulent layer.
(d) a turbulent boundary layer is more likely to separate.
questions.solution: (a) a turbulent boundary layer has more kinetic energy.

questions.question: When considering the aerodynamic forces acting on an aerofoil section:

questions.solution: (a) lift and drag increase linearly with an increase in angle of attack.

questions.question: An aircraft at a weight of 237 402N stalls at 132 kt. At a weight of 356 103N it would

(c) Increase the camber of the wing.
questions.solution: (a) Decelerate the air over the top surface.

questions.question: What is true regarding deployment of slats / Krueger flaps?
options: (a) Slats increase the critical angle of attack, Krueger flaps do not.
(b) Krueger flaps increase the critical angle of attack, slats do not.
(c) Krueger flaps form a slot, Slats do not.
(d) Slats form a slot, Krueger flaps do not.
questions.solution: (a) Slats increase the critical angle of attack, Krueger flaps do not.

questions.question: What must happen to the C
What pitching moment will be generated when Fowler flaps are deployed on an
options: (c) The nose-up pitching moment will be balanced by the nose-down pitching
(d) The resultant aircraft pitching moment will depend upon the relative position

questions.question: When trailing edge flaps are deployed:
options: (a) a higher angle of attack is required for maximum lift.
questions.solution: (a) a higher angle of attack is required for maximum lift.

questions.question: Which of the following increases the stall angle?
A low wing jet aircraft is flaring to land.  The greatest stick force will be
options: (a) flaps up and CG at the aft limit.
(b) flaps fully down and Cg at the aft limit.
(c) flaps fully down and CG at the forward limit.
(d) flaps fully up and Cg at the forward limit.
questions.solution: (a) flaps up and CG at the aft limit.

questions.question: Positive static lateral stability is the tendency of an aeroplane to:
options: (a) roll to the right in the case of a positive sideslip angle (aeroplane nose to the
(b) roll to the left in the case of a positive sideslip angle (aeroplane nose to the
(c) roll to the left in a right turn.
(d) roll to the right in a right turn.
questions.solution: (a) roll to the right in the case of a positive sideslip angle (aeroplane nose to the

questions.question: Positive static longitudinal stability means:
options: (a) nose-down pitching moment when encountering an up gust.
(b) nose-up pitching moment with a speed change at a constant angle of attack.
(c) nose-down pitching moment with a speed change at a constant angle of
(d) nose-up moment when encountering an up gust.
questions.solution: (a) nose-down pitching moment when encountering an up gust.

questions.question: The CG of an aeroplane is in a fixed position forward of the neutral point.  Speed
options: (a) An increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at low speed has more affect
(b) Increase of speed generates pull forces.
(c) Aeroplane nose-up trim decreases the stick force stability.
(d) Stick force stability is not affected by trim.
questions.solution: (a) An increase of 10 kt from the trimmed position at low speed has more affect

questions.question: Too much lateral static stability is undesirable because:
options: (a) too much aileron needed in a cross-wind landing.
(b) too much rudder needed in a cross-wind landing.
(c) constant aileron in cruise in a cross-wind.
questions.solution: (a) too much aileron needed in a cross-wind landing.

questions.question: What is the effect of an aft shift of the CG on (1) static longitudinal stability and (2)
Which statement is correct?
options: (a) The stick force per ‘g’ increases when the CG is moved aft.
(b) The stick force per ‘g’ must have both upper and lower limits in order to
(c) If the slope of the fe-n line becomes negative, generally speaking this is not a
(d) The stick force per ‘g’ can only be corrected by means of electronic devices
questions.solution: (a) The stick force per ‘g’ increases when the CG is moved aft.

questions.question: What is pitch angle?
options: (a) The angle between the chord line and the horizontal plane.
(b) The angle between the longitudinal axis and the horizontal plane.
(c) The angle between the chord line and the longitudinal axis.
(d) The angle between the relative airflow and the longitudinal axis.
questions.solution: (a) The angle between the chord line and the horizontal plane.

questions.question: An aircraft of 50 tonnes mass, with two engines each of 60 000 N Thrust and with
In a straight steady descent:
options: (a) Lift is less than weight, load factor is equal to one.
(b) Lift is less than weight, load factor is less than one.
(c) Lift is equal to weight, load factor is equal to one.
(d) Lift is equal to weight, load factor is less than one.
questions.solution: (a) Lift is less than weight, load factor is equal to one.

questions.question: Two aircraft of the same weight and under identical atmospheric conditions are
options: (a) the turn radius of ‘A’ will be greater than ‘B’.
(b) the coefficient of lift of ‘A’ will be less than ‘B’.
(c) the load factor of ‘A’ is greater than ‘B’.
(d) rate of turn of ‘A’ is greater than ‘B’.
questions.solution: (a) the turn radius of ‘A’ will be greater than ‘B’.

questions.question: Assuming ISA conditions, which statement with respect to the climb is correct?
options: (a) At constant TAS the Mach number decreases.
(b) At constant Mach number the IAS increases.
(c) At constant IAS the TAS decreases.
(d) At constant IAS the Mach number increases.
questions.solution: (a) At constant TAS the Mach number decreases.

questions.question: The regime of flight from the critical Mach number (M
The speed range between high and low speed buffet:
options: (a) decreases during a descent at a constant Mach number.
(b) is always positive at Mach numbers below M
(c) increases during a descent at a constant IAS.
questions.solution: (a) decreases during a descent at a constant Mach number.

questions.question: When does the bow wave first appear?
What can happen to the aeroplane structure flying at a speed just exceeding V
options: (a) It may suffer permanent deformation if the elevator is fully deflected upwards.
(b) It may break if the elevator is fully deflected upwards.
(c) It may suffer permanent deformation because the flight is performed at to
(d) It will collapse if a turn is made.
questions.solution: (a) It may suffer permanent deformation if the elevator is fully deflected upwards.

questions.question: Which of the following can affect V
With a vertical gust, what is the point called where the change in the vertical
A single-engine aircraft with a constant speed propeller is in a gliding descent with
The advantage of a constant speed propeller over a fixed pitch propeller is:
options: (d) nearly maximum efficiency over wide speed range.

questions.question: You are about to take off in an aircraft with a variable pitch propeller.  At brake
